VLIB_erode_bin_mask

Detailed Description


Functions

void VLIB_erode_bin_mask (const uint8_t *restrict in_data, uint8_t *restrict out_data, const int8_t *restrict mask, int32_t cols, int32_t pitch)

Function Documentation

void VLIB_erode_bin_mask ( const uint8_t *restrict  in_data,
uint8_t *restrict  out_data,
const int8_t *restrict  mask,
int32_t  cols,
int32_t  pitch 
)

Description:
This function implements binary erosion using an arbitrary 3x3 mask. The mask differs from the 3x3 square mask in that any 3x3 mask combination of 1's and 0's may be passed. The end result, for each mask placement over the input image, is that all image pixels corresponding to zero mask values are disregarded and don't contribute to the binary product. The erosion operator generates output pixels by performing a binary AND of all pixels under non-zero input mask values to generate an output pixel at the location of the center pixel of the mask. Input and output are bit-packed binary images. So, every bit of input and output images represents a pixel.
Parameters:
[in] in_data Input image pointer (32-bit packed binary, UQ8.0)
[out] out_data Output image pointer (32-bit packed binary, UQ8.0)
[in] mask Binary 3x3 erosion mask pointer (SQ7.0)
[in] cols Number of pixels (bits) to be processed (SQ31.0)
[in] pitch Pitch of the input image (SQ31.0)
Assumptions:
  • I/O buffers are assumed to be four byte aligned and not aliased.
  • The inputs cols and pitch must be multiples of 32.
  • The bit-packed input and output are ordered the same way as pixels in the image. This is different from the IMGLIB requirement for bit-reversed binary pixels within 32-bit words.
  • If the data is a region of interest within a larger image, then pitch < cols.
  • The function causes a shift in the output image with respect to the input image. The shift is one pixel to the left and one pixel to the top. See Output Shift by Filtering Functions for more information. The vertical shift can be avoided by passing pointer to the second row of output as the argument out_data to the function. Since the image is 32-bit backed binary data, horizontal shift cannot be avoided.
  • Border pixels will not contain valid data, in particular, the first and last row (if input and output are vertically aligned), as well as two rightmost columns of the output do not contain valid data.
  • Every element of the mask should be either 0 or 1.
Implementation Notes:
  • This code is fully interruptible
  • This code is compatible with C6XXX fixed-point processors
Benchmarks:
See VLIB_Test_Report.html for cycle and memory information.
